comments.commentBody: The good Pope's heartfelt Catholicism and magnanimous humanity is fundamentally incompatible with conservative American Protestantism, which celebrates the haunting fear that someone, somewhere, may be happy.

And what, Socrates, are you qualifications to opine on the thinking of either Catholics or American Protestants?

You seem, once again, to be painting with an overly broad brush with your usual gratuitousness.
I am shocked that Socrates has something nice to say about the Catholic Church.  There is still hope for the world.

You have plagiarized the late Christopher Hitchens, and badly (who was quoting the later Mencken, by the way). The only original contribution you have made, as usual, is to clutter a predictable sentiment with too many words in an attempt to sound smart--and inserting a political statement, even if you have to assault the topic to force it to fit.

When, Socrates, will you begin to bore yourself, as you have so many of the rest of us?

If you cannot recognise the obvious journalistic bias at work in the NYT since Trump got elected then, my dear, you have your head in the sand.  One would have to be completely clueless not to take issue with the NYT's coverage of Trump.  I didn't vote for him, but I can certainly see that I am not going to get the objective investigative journalism I need to form opinions in these pages.  As to the other comments, NYT readers are famous for their epistemic closure.  One can only pity them.

The meetings that Sessions had with the Russian ambassador were meaningless and had nothing to do with the election. The first meeting was actually set up by the Obama state department. There were a hundred ambassadors from a hundred countries. Sessions could be said to meet with all of them. The second meeting was in his senate office involving the Senate Armed Service and was nothing but routine. There were three other people in the office at the time. That was reported by the NYT. Two army officers and an assistant.
What I think happened is when questioned by Al Frankenstein Sessions really didn't remember the meetings. He may still not remember the meetings. The details that he is sharing now may have been told to him by the others in his senate office at the time. Sessions biggest embarrassment from all this is his apparent lack of memory. The only lie he may be telling is he remembers the meeting now.

It's difficult right now not to spiral into a vortex of depressed cynicism. One thing that gives me hope for our country eventually coming to its senses is reading Paul's well-reasoned writing. I remember back in the run-up to the Iraq war, when it was anathema to question the reasoning for our country taking out Saddam Hussein, to the point of being considered unpatriotic. At that time, Paul's continued reasoned insistence of our country's error eventually was proven correct. And public opinion eventually followed.

It may take the entirety of Trump's term in office (assuming he makes it four years). But I remain convinced that the error of his policies will reveal themselves to the rest of America. The sad part is that in order for that to come to fruition, many people are going to suffer. And necessarily our country will be worse off for it, too.

I agree this is heartbreaking - an devastating outcome.

Our situation, however is not nonsense.
Where we find ourselves now is because of another type of corruption that will destroy us from within.

People have already been hurt. Mosques have burnt. Jewish cemeteries have been desecrated and community caters have had well over 100 bomb threats within the last several weeks.
Our current government is looking into separating undocumented women from their children in detention, deporting people for minor long-ago misdemeanors or when they drop their children off at school .. who does that?
only the cruelest of the cruel willingly and willfully separate families.

(this is my cuppa, if you couldn't tell...
So it is with all the regionalist writers who, in our time, preserve the actual rhythms and patterns of speech, through variant spellings and unusual vocabulary and idiomatic usages, from Alice Walker and Walt Kelly to John Steinbeck, Eudora Welty and Harper Lee, W.P. Kinsella, Toni Morrison, Stephen King, Annie Proulx, Doris Betts, on and on, who will serve hundreds of years from now - [if the the world still exists four years from now] - to attest to language & language change in the 20th-21st centuries.)

Your observation is projection, that says more about you than me. I note that attempting (and failing) to use "atheist" as a term of disparagement is rich, considering the low nature of belief in the supernatural from elves to ghosts to gods.

Further if one were to need a motive for bitterness, in say a novel, then 1500 years over which a society could not wrest itself from ignorance of magical thinking about sky daddies and human sacrifice would suffice nicely, methinks;)

Compassionate people who concentrate on the good in humanity are always considered to be foolish by some. But I say that we live up to expectations, good or bad. Concentrating on the good is the least foolish path.

People are so afraid of being wrong that they don't take the chance to do right.

Sure, your act of compassion might turn out badly- we live in an imperfect world. But give anyway, in the most effective way you can, because most of the time, we are all better for it.
So you get the right to judge this person, on a second or two observation? Christianity can be uncomfortable at times, can't it?

In these times when public rhetoric has taken a turn for the brutal (a bully in the White House) and strongmen are on the rise, this is salve to the soul.

Pope Francis reminds us that bad leaders will have little power if we ignore their calls to hate by stopping, reflecting, and putting ourselves in the shoes of the beggar as a fellow human being, no different than us.

Imagine if there were one day of the year when we all followed his sage advice.

What a world it could be.

I do notice that the Catholic Churh, of which Pope Francis is the head, has yet to volunteer to dispose of some of the more valuable, non-religious assets all over the world to fund some of the programs that he espouses.

The Vatican Art Museum serves no useful purpose other than to extol the grandeur of The Church during its centuries of existence.

Francis, thank you.
When I was in difficulties, I was shown much mercy by strangers on the street, including the homeless.
Yesterday I was in New York and didn't give anyone anything. Usually I do, but I didn't have any singles.
In future I'll be sure to carry a few. You never know who you'll meet.
Sure, some people are lying, but I'm still better off than they are.

Let's contrast the approach of Pope Francis to that well known "centrist progressive" Tony Blair in dealing with a panhandler. The Pope advocates giving without reservation, no strings, but Mr. Blair would however, size up the mendicant & if finding he or she to be within the acceptable age range, would give the coinage as well as directions to the nearest military recruiter.
This can be said to giving a fishhook rather than a fish, but with however, a line attached. He might call it "compassionate centrist progressiveness".

Yeah, right. This from the people who gave us organized pedophilia and dropped money on people to shut them up, without caring about the damage they had done and then just moved the same offenders around and failed to alert people. All of this took place with official sanction all over the world.

The Catholic Church and its 'pope' have to realize they have abdicated every last scrap of their moral authority and these remarks about how much to give are meaningless, insulting, even. Ever see the 60 Minutes report on the wealth of the Vatican and the images of the priceless art they own and secret away from the world? Hey Pope, how about liquidating all that stuff and giving YOUR money away to the poor 'without worry'?

People are sheep and continue to willingly be led by charlatans like the Catholic Church and Trump.

When the Pope returns Cardinal Bernard Law to the United States to face criminal charges for his participation in the pedophile shuffling in the Dioceses of Boston and Fall River, I will grant him the presumption that he is cleaning up the act of the Catholic Church.

When will we see Cardinal Law on our shores again, sir?

Dear Apple, I know you're right from personal experience, but sometimes when I'm confronted by people who are wolfin' (crying alarm when there isn't any) I give them money anyway. People who have to resort to such tactics are living in difficulty, much more so than I.
I already gave in the form of taxation. It is the government duty to take care of people in need. It is certainly less humiliating for all involved

Yes--well-- it's not enough. And in this coming cycle it will be less. So if you can spare anything , please take your opportunities, because what's humiliating is standing outside with your ask while people shuffle by with their heads down.

an apple a day,

Your response is the generic one that Pope Francis is counteracting. If the nonprofits and "agencies" were doing such a great job, we would not have homeless people in the streets. This subject is about heart not about head.

Incompetence, petulance, braggadocio and hubris are the 4 horsemen who will define this presidency. The incompetence of not only the daily actions and non-actions in running the nation's affairs is stunning, as is the incompetence and incoherence reflected daily in the addled tweets, bizarre steam-of-consciousness shrink sessions (press briefings) and ham-handed attempts at diversions. The petulance of administration enablers rushed out to the "enemy" (media) makes Alice in Wonderland seem sane and normal. The braggadocio in proceeding with the evisceration of safeguards, regulations and the agencies charged with enforcement will damage us all for generations is breath-taking (literally), while the hubris of claiming a mandate with the diversion of "fake news", "alternative facts", "phantom alien voters who all voted for Hillary", "Obama wire taps, coup plotters and compliant allies" reflects a systemic illness (and probably a physical one) that needs lots of treatment.
The Watergate flashbacks are so surreal, and it seems the question is not "What did the president know and when did he know it" but more like "How long has the president been compromised and how many of his coterie involved?"
The GOP Congress has to decide if they want to put the country's best interest over party politics and the diversions underway by Trump, Bannon and company. The republic's fate is in their hands.

I thought IN THE LINE OF FIRE first too, Suzy, and I was ready to complain that those who are there are often *not* targeted.  Luckily, I was grabbed by the PECS and shown the correct and complaint-free entry.

Trump probably feels that his worst problem is the demise of the "Celebrity Apprentice," which Arnold has just quit due to Trump's "baggage."

Perhaps the Donald should return to his spot as the rightful king of the "Celebrity Apprentice" because the spinoff "Presidential Apprentice" is also on the verge of being cancelled.
Perhaps they just shared a common fondness for borsht

Consider this scenario preinternet era
Russian agents or spies brake in the democratic
party building, open all the mail and correspondence between the Presidential candidate and the surrogates and publish it. There would be an imaginable uproar and almost war like atmosphere.
That situation would be beyond imagination.
Fast forward to last October. Russian agents did exactly the same thing by hacking into Dem's e mails
via internet and Republicans are OK with it? What is the difference between the two scenarios?
but what would Jesus have done?
I always look for your comments and never fail to be inspired by them whatever the subject. Thank you.
Amen. God bless the Pope.
